content: The "Fairness and Equity Tax Act of 1995" is introduced, which includes a minimum tax on certain foreign and foreign-owned corporations under Subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Fairness and Equity Tax Act of 1995" imposes a minimum tax on corporations with 90% taxable income from each business category. Applies to domestic corporations that are 25% foreign-owned or foreign corporations with gross income. The "Fairness and Equity Tax Act of 1995" imposes a minimum tax on corporations with 90% taxable income from each business category. This section applies to corporations that are 25% foreign-owned or foreign corporations with gross income effectively connected to a trade or business within the United States and substantial foreign-related person transactions during the taxable year. There is an exception where an alternative method approved by the Secretary can be used. The section imposes a minimum tax on corporations meeting specific criteria, including being foreign-owned or having gross income connected to a US trade or business with substantial foreign-related transactions. An exception exists if a qualified section 482 agreement is in effect at the time of filing the tax return. The section imposes a minimum tax on certain corporations, but this does not apply if a qualified section 482 agreement is in effect at the time of filing the tax return. The minimum tax is imposed on certain corporations unless a qualified section 482 agreement is in effect for the tax return, ensuring a clear reflection of transactions with related parties in different business activities. The Secretary may enter into a qualified section 482 agreement to ensure a clear reflection of taxable income from related party transactions in different business activities, including retroactive application to prior taxable years. The Secretary may enter into a qualified section 482 agreement to ensure a clear reflection of taxable income from related party transactions in different business activities, including retroactive application to prior taxable years. If the Secretary determines that the agreement should also apply to prior years, the requirement for the agreement to be in effect when the corporation files its return may not apply for those specified years. The agreement may apply retroactively to prior taxable years without the need for it to be in effect when the corporation files its return. A minimum tax of 35 percent is imposed if the Secretary cannot categorize a corporation's activities based on the Standard Industrial Classification Code. A minimum tax of 35 percent is imposed on a corporation if the Secretary cannot categorize its activities based on the Standard Industrial Classification Code. The tax is based on 9 percent of the gross receipts from the sale or leasing of property manufactured by the taxpayer or a related foreign person. This tax does not apply in cases of casualty or disaster as determined by the Secretary. A minimum tax of 35 percent is imposed on a corporation if activities cannot be categorized based on the Standard Industrial Classification Code. The tax is based on 9 percent of gross receipts from the sale or leasing of property manufactured by the taxpayer or a related foreign person. The tax does not apply in cases of casualty or disaster as determined by the Secretary. Foreign taxes are not considered in determining taxable income. The Secretary may waive the minimum tax if deemed inequitable due to casualty or disaster. Foreign taxes are excluded from taxable income calculations. The Secretary sets applicable profit percentages for different business categories annually. The Secretary sets applicable profit percentages for different business categories annually based on average earnings rates of domestic corporations. The Secretary sets applicable profit percentages for different business categories annually based on average earnings rates of domestic corporations. The profit percentage is determined by the earnings rate of domestic corporations from specific business activities. The earnings rate of a domestic corporation is based on the ratio of adjusted book income to gross receipts from specific business activities, disregarding certain taxes. The term 'adjusted book income' refers to income reported for financial purposes without considering certain taxes. Definitions and special rules apply for 25-percent foreign-owned entities and substantial foreign-related person transactions. Definitions and special rules under this section include the terms '25-percent foreign-owned', 'foreign person', and 'related party' as defined in section 6038A(c). A corporation is deemed to have substantial foreign-related person transactions for a taxable year if the total amount involved in transactions with foreign-related parties exceeds $2,000,000 or 10% of the corporation's gross income for that year. The corporation has substantial foreign-related person transactions if the total amount involved with related foreign parties exceeds $2,000,000 or 10% of the corporation's gross income for the taxable year. Business activities are categorized by a 3-digit classification. The taxable income of the corporation determines the amounts taken into account. Business activities are categorized by a 3-digit classification system. The Secretary may aggregate classifications where appropriate. The Secretary may aggregate 3-digit classifications of business activities in appropriate cases, allowing for a classification system other than the Standard Industrial Classification Code when necessary. Effective Date: The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1995.
